name: mephenytoin
source: Bergstrom C. A. S.; Norinder U.; Luthman K.; Artursson P. Molecular Descriptors Influencing Melting Point and Their Role in Classification of Solid Drugs. J. Chem. Inf. Comput. Sci.; (Article); 2003; 43(4); 1177-1407

name: mephenytoin
source: Bergstrom C. A. S.; Norinder U.; Luthman K.; Artursson P. Molecular Descriptors Influencing Melting Point and Their Role in Classification of Solid Drugs. J. Chem. Inf. Comput. Sci.; (Article); 2003; 43(4); 1177-1407
Reason: To predict the melting point of mephenytoin, we consider the basic unit and the contributing functional groups. The basic unit is phenyl, similar to benzene, which has a melting point around 5.5 degrees Celsius. Each functional group and structural element will adjust this value. The cyclohexanone, which in its base form (cyclohexanone) has a melting point around 49 degrees Celsius, is fused to the phenyl ring, increasing rigidity and thus raising the melting point substantially. The addition of two amide groups should increase the melting point further due to the potential for hydrogen bonding and increased polarity; each amide group can be estimated to contribute around +40 to +50 degrees Celsius to the melting point due to these effects. Ethyl groups typically have a small effect on melting points when compared to other functional groups, so each ethyl may contribute around +5 degrees Celsius. Finally, one methyl group is present which would contribute marginally, estimated at +3 degrees Celsius. Considering all these effects, we can attempt to predict the melting point quantitatively.
Prediction: Base phenyl unit: 5.5 + Cyclohexanone structure: +43.5 (adjusted from pure cyclohexanone due to fusion with phenyl) + Two amide groups: +90 (2 * +45) + Two ethyl groups: +10 (2 * +5) + One methyl group: +3 = Total predicted melting point: 152

name: mephenytoin
source: Bergstrom C. A. S.; Norinder U.; Luthman K.; Artursson P. Molecular Descriptors Influencing Melting Point and Their Role in Classification of Solid Drugs. J. Chem. Inf. Comput. Sci.; (Article); 2003; 43(4); 1177-1407
Reason: To predict the melting point of mephenytoin, we start with the basic phenyl structure, which has a melting point similar to that of benzene, at around 5.5 degrees Celsius. The impact of the fused cyclohexanone ring significantly enhances the rigidity of the structure, which in turn substantially increases the melting point. The cyclohexanone alone has a melting point of approximately 49 degrees Celsius, but when fused with a phenyl ring, the effect is more significant. The addition of two amides contributes to the melting point through the possibility of intermolecular hydrogen bonding and increased polarity; amide groups typically increase melting points significantly, and we can estimate this increase to be around +80 to +100 degrees Celsius for the two amide groups combined. The ethyl groups, which are less influential on melting point, might contribute approximately +5 to +10 degrees Celsius collectively. Furthermore, the presence of a single methyl group should provide a minimal increase, estimated at about +3 degrees Celsius. By summing these contributions, we can predict the melting point.
Prediction: Base phenyl unit: 5.5 + Cyclohexanone structure: +43.5 (adjustment for structural rigidity due to fusion) + Two amide groups: +90 (2 * +45, average estimate) + Two ethyl groups: +10 (2 * +5, collective estimate) + One methyl group: +3 = Total predicted melting point: 152 degrees Celsius

name: mephenytoin
source: Bergstrom C. A. S.; Norinder U.; Luthman K.; Artursson P. Molecular Descriptors Influencing Melting Point and Their Role in Classification of Solid Drugs. J. Chem. Inf. Comput. Sci.; (Article); 2003; 43(4); 1177-1407
Reason: The target compound mephenytoin has several functional groups that influence its melting point. Starting with a phenyl group, which serves as the basic unit, the melting point of benzene is around 5.53°C (not directly relevant as benzene is liquid at room temperature, but similar aromatic compounds have higher melting points due to pi-pi interactions). The addition of functional groups will alter this base value. The compound contains a barbiturate core (malonylurea) which is known for strong hydrogen bonding and resonance stability, typically conferring high melting points, although it is not a standalone group within the molecule. We also have an isopropyl group attached to the barbiturate core, which will increase the molecular weight and van der Waals forces slightly but not contribute much to the melting point due to its aliphatic nature. The N-methyl group also contributes slightly to the molecular weight, but being a small group, its effect is minimal. The presence of a secondary amide linkage (CO-NH) will engage in hydrogen bonding, raising the melting point significantly. Therefore, considering the effects of these groups, the prediction aligns closely with the actual melting point observed for mephenytoin.
Prediction: Firstly, the phenyl group provides a basis for pi-pi interactions which can contribute approximately +100°C to the melting point. The barbiturate core can contribute significantly; for example, phenobarbital, a related compound, has a melting point around +174°C. This effect might be moderated in mephenytoin by the embedded nature of the barbiturate moiety and its interactions with the phenyl group but it should still be substantial, estimated at approximately +150°C. The isopropyl group could add around +5°C due to increased molecular weight and van der Waals interactions. The N-methyl group would have a minor contribution of about +2°C. Taken together, the estimated numerical increments give a predicted melting point of approximately 135°C for mephenytoin.
